_header: For love I mourn and sorrow make
_description: ‘Amore langueo’ — two couplets as introductio thematis in a Latin homily, Dominica in passione vel in die parasceue, perhaps by John Bromyard

CULKk424.Transcription:
for loue y morney persche al for þy sakey hope al yn
                    þy gracemy lyfe ys on þy face
CULKk424.Editions:
Wenzel,  Siegfried. 
             Preachers, Poets and the English Lyric.
         Princeton: Princeton Univ. Press, 1986: 237-8.

OxfBal149.Transcription:
For loue I morne & sorowe makeFor morninge y perische for þi
                    sakeThough y perysche y hope þi graceMy lyue my hope ys in
                    þi face
OxfBal149.Note:
Written as verse; second occurrence; added to lower margin of page by a
                    hand of the fifteenth century.

OxfMagd93.Transcription:
for loue y peryssh al for thy sakeI hope yn thy gracemy loue ys
                    yn thy swete facethat thou will me take
OxfMagd93.Note:
Written as prose, here with lines out of order such that rhyme is
                    abba.

TCD277.Transcription:
for luf I moreneI periche all for þi sakeI hope þi
                    gracemy lyf es all on þi face

Amore langueo (p. 185); sermo de passione Cristi in die
